paragraphs.text: Mental illness never really goes away, you see. There’s no cure. You find your own recipe as best you can and you manage it as best you can. It gets exhausting, because sometimes the recipe changes and you have to change with it. People get tired. Carrie Fisher got tired. She kept going.
paragraphs.name: 34b9

paragraphs.text: Mental illness never really goes away, you see. There’s no cure. You find your own recipe as best you can and you manage it as best you can. It gets exhausting, because sometimes the recipe changes and you have to change with it. People get tired. Carrie Fisher got tired. She kept going.
paragraphs.name: 34b9
78d6
paragraphs.text: After I finished doing the stage show but before the book came out, I found myself freelancing as a writer with no health insurance. This was before Obamacare, and it was still legal for insurance companies to refuse to cover you because you’d dared get sick ever in your life. This was called a “pre-existing condition.” I had been depressed more than once, so nobody wanted to let me pay them exorbitant fees in order to obtain care to ensure that I didn’t get depressed again.

paragraphs.name: e57b
paragraphs.text: When I was a kid and the school referred my folks to a social worker (something I thought was common practice until I grew up and learned it wasn’t), I remember that deeply empathetic, underpaid woman telling me that plenty of very accomplished people got depressed or anxious. She explained to me the difference between what I had (depression) and manic depression (bipolar disorder). She told me that Mike Wallace of “60 Minutes” had depression and that Carrie Fisher had manic depression, and that they both spoke openly about it to help people. I wasn’t that into “Star Wars” yet, but I knew Carrie Fisher was famous and talented and pretty and I had thought she was very funny when somebody accidentally let me watch “When Harry Met Sally.” I remember as a kid I liked her voice. It was a very soothing voice, I thought. So elegant.

2016 has taught me that one measure of a life well-lived is that when you die, you emotionally destroy tons of people who never met you. Congratulations, Carrie, you magnificent bitch. In the end of the year, you motherfucked us all.

paragraphs.text: I interviewed Carrie, Harrison Ford and Mark Hamill back when the first Star Wars was released. Roger Ebert gave me a huge press premiere ticket that almost put me off going to see it — as I recall, it was a gigantic Millennium Falcon or something of the sort. So I thought it was going to be some kind of kid’s movie. But I was enthralled by both the…

da3aa38879a.title: Thanks for sharing this Sara, it’s a great tribute to Carrie Fisher.

paragraphs.text: Thanks for sharing this Sara, it’s a great tribute to Carrie Fisher. You eloquently put into words so many of the things I was thinking abour her life and death. I hope you have a long, interesting and mostly happy life and that you leave many strangers heart-broken when you finally leave. ❤
paragraphs.name: c0a3

paragraphs.text: So infuriating condition! How can any insurance company not cover the fee ever? For the reason that sickness is inevitable. Of course it is unavoidable and it’s tough to find out cure for illness like this, still it’s their responsibility to not oversee one’s life just like a pig’s.

a984bf0cccab.title: All of us who have suffered from mental health issues or who have loved ones who do owe Carrie…

paragraphs.text: All of us who have suffered from mental health issues or who have loved ones who do owe Carrie Fisher our gratitude for being the trailblazer she was. The Force will always be strong in that one. Thanks for many, now and forever.
paragraphs.name: a0dd

paragraphs.text: Sweet and wonderful. Thank you, Sara, for your honesty and wit, two qualities of which we are in dire need these days.
paragraphs.name: e2ec

paragraphs.text: Thanks for this, Sara. To keep going while living with mental health challenges is a daily choice, and — as you so rightly point out — it gets fucking exhausting at times. And yet, to give up would mean to give in — this would never be *my* choice but that of Depression, the invisible dog in my head, and the mutt is not in charge, I am! So I shall…
paragraphs.name: 52c7

paragraphs.text: A perfect tribute, Sara!
paragraphs.name: 9ab5

paragraphs.text: This was magnificent. I have been quietly weeping on and off for the last 24 hours… since learning my childhood icon and adulthood hero had fucking died. You just encapsulated everything I felt and continue to feel beautifully. Dear god… 2016, you have kicked the asses of women who grew up in the 70’s and 80’s beyond measure. And we have 2017 to look…
paragraphs.name: cc4e

paragraphs.text: Good God, this is fantastic.
paragraphs.name: fcf0

78c975a411aa.title: Not true. Mental illness can be cured and you won’t believe how.

paragraphs.text: Not true. Mental illness can be cured and you won’t believe how. I cured our son’s schizophrenia. Within a couple of years his addictions pushed him back into psychosis. His meds (an extremely small dosage) made him worse. I started him on music therapy again, focused on his right ear, and within the year had cured him again and had written a book…

Such a force. I have kept a couple of things she said close to me. “I think people confuse celebrity with acceptance, with love, with approval. These people are going to love you, then you can love yourself. It’s attention, how bad can attention be?” hmmmm. That is the tip of the iceberg for her wisdom. Her mom had that same wit. They both are every…
paragraphs.name: ebbd

paragraphs.text: Beautifully written
paragraphs.name: 34f5

e07c79acea8f.title: Carrie Fisher is the reason I’m considering ECT.

paragraphs.text: Carrie Fisher is the reason I’m considering ECT. I heard her talk about it openly years ago on a talk show. I’d always loved her, but I loved her more when she talked about her depression and treatment. After years of taking many different kinds of medication, I have reached a point where I’m considering other alternates. Carrie gave me that courage.
paragraphs.name: e6e2
